4.text:
My name’s Jessica Ennis and I’m the world
indoor and outdoor heptathlon

9.text:
champion. I first got involved in athletics
when I was about 9 or 10 and I came to

15.text:
Don Valley where they had a summer camp every
year, so I came along and tried

21.text:
all the different events out and really enjoyed
it, so I decided to come back the

27.text:
I think when I was at the age of about 15,
that was the kind of turning point

31.text:
where I thought, you know, this is fun and
I enjoy it, but now I want to take it a

36.text:
little bit more seriously, and that was kind
of the point where I realised that

41.text:
potentially athletics could be a career for
me.

47.text:
In the past I’ve always had school, and
6th form, and university to juggle with, but

51.text:
now I have the opportunity to just train full
time and just really focus on my

56.text:
athletics a hundred percent. I train, I make
sure I recover properly, I can get

61.text:
ready for competition properly and not have
the worry of essays on the back of

66.text:
I would hate to be in a 9 to 5 job, you know,
behind a desk. I get to come out here,

72.text:
I’m outside quite a bit, I get to train,
I keep fit, have a healthy lifestyle, travel

77.text:
around the world, you know, it’s just a
brilliant job to have. Competing for your

81.text:
country is one of the biggest honours, to
be able to travel around, meet different

86.text:
people, put on your Great Britain vest, it’s
the best feeling in the world.

93.text:
The difference between the Pentathlon and
the Heptathlon is basically, we have

98.text:
an indoor and an outdoor season in athletics,
and the Pentathlon is part of the

103.text:
indoor season, simply because you can’t
throw javelin indoors so they have to

108.text:
take the javelin out and they take the 200
metres out.

110.text:
You obviously have to be really well conditioned
for the event, so you can do all

116.text:
the events together, so yeah, it’s a lot
of training and a lot of physio and massage

122.text:
so that you’re making sure that everything’s
in line, everything’s neutral and you

125.text:
can push yourself, but I think the main thing
that’s really important when you’re

130.text:
training for Heptathlon, is that you’ve
got a great coach that’s got a great plan,

133.text:
that can structure everything for you so you’re
doing a heavy session one day,

139.text:
lighter session the next day, so everything’s
balanced well so you can get the best

147.text:
I train normally twice a day, so I get up
in the morning, do a morning session

154.text:
from about 9 or half past 9, that would normally
last about 3 hours, and then I’d

159.text:
have a break, go home for lunch, walk my dog,
and then come back and do

164.text:
another session, which would be again about
3 hours. And each day is slightly

169.text:
different because obviously I have to cover
each of the events in the Heptathlon,

173.text:
but each week stays the same, so it’s really
structured and really programmed.

179.text:
And then I have physio once a week, soft tissue
therapy twice a week so every

184.text:
day is quite full, and obviously when it comes
to my rest day, I enjoy just

189.text:
switching off and relaxing a little bit. I’m
quite lucky because training’s so hard

195.text:
for the Heptathlon so you can get away with
having the odd treat, because you

198.text: burn it off the next day in training.

201.text:
Obviously you do have those days when you
don’t want to get out of bed, and it’s

204.text:
raining, and you don’t want to go and do
a horrible running session on the track,

207.text:
but you drag yourself out of bed because,
well, I’m personally really motivated by

212.text:
winning medals, and making championships,
and improving on what I’ve done in

217.text:
the past, and that’s what gets me to those
training sessions when I’m not feeling

224.text:
I think it was two months before the Olympics
were due to start; I found out I

228.text:
had three stress factors in my foot. So that
was a massive disappointment and a

233.text:
really tough thing for me to deal with. As
a result of my injury, me and my coach

237.text:
and the physio's made the decision that I
was going to change my take off foot for

241.text:
the long jump, just to take the pressure off
my right foot, and to stop an injury

246.text:
like that happening in the future. So yeah,
it was quite a frustrating process; it

251.text:
was like changing hands, from your left hand
to your right hand, but it was just

257.text:
something I had to do to make sure I didn’t
get injured in the same way again. So

263.text:
the year after, the World Championships in
Berlin was a massive focus for me,

267.text:
and I just wanted to get everything right
to go there and I wanted to win a

270.text:
medal… So to go there and perform the way
I did… I was leading the competition

275.text:
from the first event to the last event. And
then to stand there on the podium and

279.text:
to have a gold medal put over my neck was
just the best feeling ever, you know,

284.text:
something really special, that I’ll remember
for the rest of my life.

291.text:
I was probably born with quite a competitive
streak in me and I think it’s the way

298.text:
I’ve been brought up, and I think that starting
athletics at a really young age, it

303.text:
kind of installs some really important qualities
in you; it makes you disciplined, it

308.text:
makes you a little bit more focused in all
parts of your life. It’s a massive

312.text:
adrenaline rush being on the track and getting
into your blocks and having the

317.text:
crowd there, and the atmosphere, knowing that
you’ve trained so hard for it and

321.text:
that that’s your time to show what you’ve
really worked for. It’s the best feeling

326.text:
in the world and when you’ve crossed that
line in the 800, and everything’s gone

330.text:
to plan, it’s really hard to describe how
amazing it feels.
